segments.text: My name is from Michael and I was born on January 22nd, 1932 in Scranton, Pennsylvania.
I was the son of an immigrant family.
My father and mother were born in Italy.
My father came here when he was two years old.
And his father was killed in a mine accident.
Mining?
Yeah, cave-in.
My father was eight years old, and he was the oldest of five children.
And he had to quit school.
These were the days before welfare.

the social and he uh he had to he was the oldest and he had to quit school and went to work as a breaker boy and what did the breaker boy do they pick coal you know they would help help miners put coal into those carts they would work they would feed the animals you know the mules that carry these cards
just odd jobs, you know, that men would probably do today, that children do today.
And so he never finished his education.
He had a third grade education.
He was a very intelligent man, very sensitive man, but never finished school.
And I think his one goal in life was to make sure that
His son, and I was his only son, went to college and didn't have to do what he did.
Sort of the classic immigrant story.
My grandfather and grandmother went to Germany, so I kind of know what you're talking about.
They wanted to get their son educated, which they did.
And then he, of course, wanted to make sure we were educated, which he did.
I can remember ever since I was a little boy, five or six years old, my mother stressing the importance of how I had to become educated and go to college.
So I was the first one in our family to go to college.
Where did you go?
Tell me, now you grew up in Scranton.
I grew up in Scranton, Pennsylvania.
went to college at Penn State.
And did your father stay in the mines while you were growing up?
Yes, he did.
He became, when he was an adult, he got a better job in the mines than what he had as a breaker boy.
He became a carpenter.
And so he was the guy who repaired
The machinery that they used in breakers, and I don't know if you know what a breaker is, but a breaker is the place where they refine the coal after they take it out of the ground.
And they have, you know, they put it through treatment of various kinds of water, and what else they do.
They clean up the coal, and they put it into certain sizes.
So they had equipment that had to be maintained, and he was a carpenter in that breaker.
And he would go into the mines when they would cave in and shore them up and that sort of thing.
So they were kind of jack of all trades.
They were not fine carpenters, but people who built heavy structures.
And where did you go to school?
At undergraduate school at Penn State.
And did you have an assistantship, or work your way through, or your family put you through?
I had a scholarship, and in those days, as you know, it was not expensive to go to college, at a state school particularly, but I had a scholarship.
Yeah, I imagine Penn State and A&M are very popular.
Yeah, they're sort of peer institutions, both land grant institutions.
And I was a biology major, and in those days,
My goal was to become a biology professor.
How about that?
Yeah, I wanted to get a PhD.
That's interesting.
I was an embryologist.
I went to graduate school at Ohio State.
And after getting my master's degree, before I got my master's degree, I got married.
I got married while in graduate school.
And you got your master's at Ohio State?
Yeah.
And while there, I met a woman in class that I married, and I began to question whether I really wanted to teach and do research.
And then I think getting married sort of also said to me, I better get out and start earning a living instead of staying at school.
So I think those two factors convinced me that I should probably start working.
And while teaching a biology laboratory course, I used to talk to this one guy who was a salesman who used to try to get me to adopt.
lab manuals that I was using in the course.
And he got me interested in publishing.
He told me what he did.
And I always loved doing this.
So as most people who go into this profession, they're never trained for it.
But one of the things I have in common is a love of books.
And everyone I'm sure you've talked to who's been in this business has said that.
And I was the same way.
And so I became a textbook salesman.
With?
the McMillan Company.
It was my first job in publishing.
Now where were you based?
I was based in Michigan, and I worked in the state of Michigan, the state of Ohio, and a third of the state of Pennsylvania.
So I traveled by place.
Where did you live in Michigan?
Outside of Detroit.
And then I did that for about two and a half years, and I got promoted
to an acquisition editorial in New York.
So we moved from Michigan to New York City.
I moved to New Jersey, but I moved to New York City, where I was an acquisitions editor.
And you'd be interested to know that I was a biology acquisition for the college division.
And one of my predecessors was James Mitchell.
No kidding.
I still remember to this day when I was going through the files.
I didn't know James Mitchell at that time.
And I started reading.
He worked in biology.
He did a lot of things.
But one of the things he did was biology.
And I remember reading letters that he had written to various people.
And he had, when he was at Macmillan, he wrote, I think he started Tales of the South Pacific, his first book.
But he got it published while he was at Macmillan.
And that was a success that he made.
And he became, that and his next book, which I can't remember what it was, might have been the one, I'm not sure.
He did the, uh, three or four in the Asian.
Yeah.
Sayonara was one.
Yeah.
And I was a Michigan fan.
Yeah, I have been, too.
Although I've never read most of his books, I must confess, including Hawaii.
Well, I read Tales of the South Pacific.
I like Caravans.
Do you remember the old one, Caravans?
And I like the Polish one, Poland.
The best book he wrote, in my opinion, was Centennial.
Centennial, yeah.
I thought it was a terrific book, mainly because I was interested in the biology and the anthropology and geology.
He wrote a lot about it.
Anyway, he then left, he left Macmillan, and there were a couple of free editors in between him and me, but I was impressed with him.
I thought he was a good editor.
He wrote very good letters.
I remember he was very conscientious, very earnest, and so
That's where I got my start.
I started in the commercial publishing business.
And I had various jobs in publishing.
I went on from being an acquisition editor to being an editorial director.
And at one point, I got into marketing because I wanted to learn the marketing side of the business.
And my last job in commercial publishing was director of marketing.
for Random House.
How long did you stay with McMillan?
I'm trying to think.
Probably 11 years or so.
Ten or 11 years.
And then to Random House, still in New York.
Still in New York, yeah.
And he was director of marketing for the school and the college divisions of Random House.
And then from there,
I went into scholarly publishing.
My first job was in scholarly publishing.
Why?
Well, mainly because I felt at that time that was the beginning of the move in commercial publishing to become like the movie business, where people wanted to do blockbuster books.
You had to do best-selling college textbooks every time out, and I was becoming

concerned about that i wanted to do books that i believed in not just books that made a lot of money and so i had friends who had gone into scholarly publishing and i remember talking to them and decided that i would make a career change and go into scholarly publishing and i became director of teachers college press
Was that a new one?
No, that has been around for a long time.
It's been an old, I'd say, when I was there it celebrated its 50th anniversary.
Oh, is that right?
Yeah, so it was started a long time ago.
It was unlike most scholarly publishers.
It was a professional publisher, not a scholarly publisher.
When did you make that move?
I went there in 1978.
Was the transition marked?
It wasn't.
It wasn't.
The only thing that was different was that you could do books that you believed in and that whether they made money or lost money was not a big issue, as long as
The press could live within its budget.
And that's one of the reasons I went, is because I wanted to be able to do books that were exciting to me, that made a contribution to me, and that were not necessarily money makers.
I was not opposed to doing books that made money.
But I wanted to do books that, more importantly, made a contribution to me.
Now, are you still, do you think, tuned in more to the science-type book as a director, as an acquisitions editor, as a whatever?
A finance book?
No, no, into science.
Oh, science.
Biology, anything.
You've left that.
I am, but I'm also very much interested in history books and anthropology.
No, I would say that I'm not...
So you never felt yourself being tilted to the science mode in particular?
No, except I had most of my experience as an editor was in that area.
So I always felt more comfortable in science because, first of all, I majored in it, and secondly, I worked as an acquisitions editor.
But when I became a marketing manager,
I also had to deal with other books.
And when I was a salesman, I was dealing with other books, not just science books.
MacMillan was a general college publisher, so they published from art to zoology.
And so I've always been exposed to other fields, and I never felt that I was inadequate in other fields or I didn't know what I was doing.
What was the size, roughly, of the Teachers College Press in terms of product?
Were they doing textbook-type things?
They were doing probably three or four types of books.
First of all, they were doing scholarly books.
They were doing professional books, books for practicing teachers.
They were doing even school books.
We did reading books for elementary and secondary school students.
And so it was a broad-based publisher in terms of the fields, not in terms of the academic field, but in terms of the type of books it published.
It focused on education, but various types of books within education.
Reference books, scholarly books, textbooks, school books.
One of the few, probably,
not the only one at the time, university presses that did books for the school, public schools.
There are very few that do that.
We did, for example, a reading series called The Call of Crabs, and they were supplementary reading books designed for primary school.
Very successful.
They did extraordinarily well.
They competed very effectively with .
I'm wondering why university professors can't paddle in those waters .
Well, some do now.
For example, Yale does a high school French program, but very few do it.
I know that.
It seems to me that's a legitimate thing.
extension of the scholarly work.
It could be viewed that way.
It's a different business and it takes a lot of financial resources to play in that game.
But there are some people that can do it.
Yale's program is one of the better high school language programs.
So you're with the
Columbia University from 78 until?
1983, when I went to the University of Pennsylvania to become director of WordPress.
And I went there because I was getting
I'm a little bored with just doing education books.
I wanted to do books in a wider variety of fields.
I wasn't bored with my job.
I enjoyed my job.
Columbia was a great place to learn.
Columbia, let me tell you, compared to a state university like A&M, is easier to work with.
The bureaucracy is about 10% of what you see in a state university.
It's much more entrepreneurial.
You can operate a university press better in a private university than you can in a state university because of all the regulations and bullshit.
And that has really increased massively, I think, in the last 20 or 30 years.
Yeah, I know.
provost, and associate provost, and assistants, and all these state regulations.
So that part is quite different.
But I was simply trying to say that I enjoyed working at Columbia.
It was a very important part of my life.
I learned the scholarly business at Columbia.
And then I went to Penn, and I was at Penn
between 1983 to 1995, when I came here.
So I was up there about 12 years.
Now, OK. What was your first M fighter, M flinger involvement with the M press?
Well, Mary Miller played a role in my coming here in the sense that I had no intentions of coming to A&M.
I knew very little about A&M.
Mary Miller sent me an email telling me what a great place this was.
Saying that they had a wonderful facility, tremendous support from their
their administration, and great financial support as well.
And why shouldn't I think about applying for this job here?
And so she got me interested, and I said,
I don't know if I really want to go there.
I'm very happy at Penn.
Although I had a strong interest in the Southwest.
And I was thinking of the days that when I retire, I probably will retire in the Southwest or the West, one of the two.
And so I decided to apply.
And it was mainly Mary Miller who got me interested.
And where did she get you from?
I don't know.
I'll ask her.
Well, I think she may, now that I think about it, she may have sent emails to various people.
I don't know.
But anyway, I was one of them.
But you're on the list.
I was one that got it.
And after I started thinking about it, and so I sent in an application.
That was when?
Probably in, yeah, I do.
It was the fall of 1994.
Now, did you know what was happening at A&M at that particular time?
Did you have any kind of know?
No.
No, I knew something about the list.
I knew that it was basically a regional publisher.
I remember someone asking me at the time, how do you view A&M?
Do you see it as a national publisher, an international publisher, a regional publisher?
Without hesitation, I said regional.
Not through any great knowledge, because I didn't make it a...
And most people probably still make that response.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Well, the faculty, particularly, I remember when I came here from Arizona, this was a big concern.
Jim Rosenheim was on the search committee.
Pam Hill was on the search committee.
Those guys were made very strong points in those meetings.
They probably made it with each applicant.
They made it with me.
That press had to reach a focus in the meeting, too.
to become a stronger publisher, with a stronger reputation, a scholarly publisher than just regional publishers.
That's a British historian speaking.
Yes.
Jim was reflecting that.
And a literature person or an English person was reflecting the same thing.
Those guys have international albums.
It's a different world.
That's all right.
A different world.
And they are not Texas historians and don't want
I didn't want this press just to publish Texas history books.
So you come to A&M for an interview.
Right.
I applied.
I got a letter from Fred Heath, and Fred Heath asked me to come down for an interview.
At that point, I gave very serious thought to what I was doing.
I didn't give it as much thought.
I said, that sounds like an interesting place.
I've never heard anyone rave so much as Mary really did about it.
It might be worth taking a look at.
But then when Fred contacted me, I gave very serious thought to it.
And I said, well, I probably am not interested in going down there.
But I've come this far, so I probably should go and find out for sure what it's like.
And you had never been here.
I had been here.
You had been here.
In 1962, I came to Texas A&M University, stayed in a motel, to see an author of ours, a guy that I had signed up to do an instructor biology with, by the name of Larry Dillman.
He's now retired.
Did you know?
Yeah.
He was a very interesting guy.
And I stayed in a hotel in Bryan.
I spent a week in here.
It was in August of 1962.
I'll never forget it.
And so that was my one time at A&M.
Now, I didn't spend much time here.
I was here a day or two just to see Larry and work with him because he was having some problems with management.
And we worked on a manuscript for two days, I remember.
And then I got back on a plane and went back to New York.
Yeah.
But I had been to A&M before.
Yeah, we were in the world in 62, and it wasn't in 92 or 94 or whatever.
And they were in that same building that they're in right now, biology.
You know, I go by that building.
Is that right?
Yeah.
I haven't been inside it, but I see it from the outside.
But I remember seeing Larry in that building.
We worked all day in his office.
And I also talked to a couple of other A&M biology professors when I was here, because I was always on the lookout for other manuscripts as well.
But I've been here.
OK.
So you come to the interview.
You're offered a job.
You're accepted.
And at that point, what is your perception of what you have done and of what this press is?
It's a regional press.
Why are you attracted to A&M?
That's a very good question, because when I told my boss that I was leaving to go to A&M, he said, why would you want to go from Pennsylvania to A&M?
Because he saw it clearly as going from a very, in his mind, a very prestigious university to one that was less prestigious.
I think what convinced me, and I
I marveled that I made the decision myself at times.
What convinced me was the people that I met here, both on the faculty and in the press.
I've never been so impressed with people that I felt were concerned, interested, positive, intelligent, motivated, and who were so enthusiastic about this place.
both the university and the press.
And what convinced me in the final analysis was the people.

The people that I met in the administration and the people I met in the administration were the search committee people, Fred Heath, Danny Parker, who was on the search committee, Ham Hill, Jim Rosenheim, whom I was very impressed with.
I remember Jim was one guy that
It was very interesting, because I admired him, I respected him, I thought he was a wonderful person.
Mary Miller, I thought she was a special person.
Bill Perry, I thought Bill was terrific.
So it was the people that convinced me.
Did you have any contact with the President's transfer types?
I did not have any contact with him.
See, that was the first time, I think, a director came in without any contact.
I was interviewed by Bill Perry, the search committee first,
But then when the search committee, I think, thought that I was a serious candidate, I was interviewed by Bill Perry and Charles Lee, who was an acting provost.
You know, the press reports into the provost's office.
And so those two guys were the people that I interviewed.
And I did not interview them.
Which was not the case when I interviewed at Columbia and Penn.
Both those jobs I reported to the provost.
But the president interviewed me in both places.
Sheldon Hackney interviewed me at Penn, and a guy named Larry Kremenz interviewed me at Teachers College and was president at Penn.
And so that struck me as
Not being strange, but I said, it sounds to me, because I knew that the press reported to the president one time, I felt that they were trying to keep it within the provost's office.
And I remember talking to Charles Lee about it.
And he said, he was saying, do you
do you feel okay about reporting to the provost rather than to the president?
And I told him, I said, well, I had always reported to the provost, but I felt that the best situation for any press is to report directly to the president.
But it wasn't enough to deter me or anything like that.
I felt the people that I had met were terrific people, and that was the basic reasoning.
I would say that this press and its staff convinced me too.
That's been a selling point all the way through the whole system.
But that is interesting that the chancellor and our president were really directly involved in talking about that.
They were not.
But that didn't bother me because I felt that there was a lot of support.
And I had taken a very hard look at the financial side of this press.
This press was in very good shape financially.
Yeah.
One of the things that many people in scholarly publishing worry about, like colleagues at other university presses, is the lack of support that they have from the administration.
This is a place that does not have that.

Despite the fact it doesn't report to the president, it still has tremendous support, and mainly because of what Frank did early on and the fact that he reported to the president and got support right from the very beginning from the people at the top of the school district.
And I think that's been a very crucial factor in the success of this class.
If Frank reported to the director of libraries or Robert Smith, this place would not be the place that it is.
He would have never had the financial support.
No, and he knew that.
He knew that instinctively, I'm sure.
And in a way, I think that probably was a mechanism to avoid being too entangled with the faculty
I'm not sure how you report it at Texas, but I do know the faculty really got his goat.
And he may have seen this as an opportunity to achieve a level of independence and deal with the faculty at arm's length instead.
Probably.
Now I feel differently about, I don't know how Frank felt, and I wouldn't make any judgments about it, but my feeling is that a press director has to spend as much time
wooing the faculty as he does the administration.
I feel that the faculty is a very important support structure for a university press.
It didn't need it here because of the support it had from the top.
Yeah, and I don't think Frank felt that, quite frankly.
The faculty were useful.
I did.
But they could be a deterrent.
Yeah, I do not feel that way.
And I think mainly because of where I've come from.
At both Columbia and Penn, the faculty is more of a governing body than it is here.
This university is governed from the top down.
The faculty does not have nearly as much say.
At Penn, the faculty had as much say about whether something survived as the president did.
And so I have always been sensitive to that, because I knew that without the support of the faculty, the press would not have support.
And I worked as hard on convincing the faculty that we were doing important things at Penn as I did convincing my boss.
Now, do you think that the fact that the press was financially secure or had a greater degree of security
provided a stronger incentive for more support from the administration.
I don't get the fact that that would ever enter into their mind, really, the financial status of the press.
No, they don't concern themselves with it.
What they're concerned about is reputation.
Is the press providing the kind of visibility to the university and to them as individuals to get published?

And, you know, there are great parts of this university's faculty, they don't give one poot about the press because the science and engineering people, the press is not a factor, but the humanities people and the literature people, I mean, those people are very dependent upon university presses for tenure and promotion.
Exactly.
In fact, I'm kind of leaning into this chapter I'm working on now, is the idea that, in fact, the climate for university presses has increased tremendously because of the imperative to publish.
The publisher parish commandment really promoted the expansion of university presses.
And that's part of that.
Good.
So that fits.
All right.
Now, to answer that first part of your question, which had to do with
Do you think that this press had the financial underpinnings that was necessary to continue its success?
You raised the question something like that.
Different words but that's what you meant.
And I think one of the reasons I came here is because I felt this press
